subsections.title: Meaning 1: next to
examples: The paper clips are beside the pens.
The ketchup is beside the lemonade.
"I hope no one sits beside me."
Beside the cottage, there is a 200-year-old well.
I was standing right beside her.
subsections.explanation: "Beside" means next to. "Right beside" = very close. Slightly more formal than "next to."

subsections.title: Meaning 2: compared with
examples: Beside Kim's poster, mine looks dull.
My cooking is no good beside my mom's.
subsections.explanation: Used to compare two things. They don't have to be physically close.

sections.heading: BESIDES
sections.note: Has two roles: preposition + adverb. Completely different meaning from "beside."

subsections.title: BESIDES (preposition) - Meaning 1: in addition to
examples: Besides glassware and ornaments, the store sells jewelry.
This store sells jewelry besides glassware and ornaments.
Besides everything we already know, no new information.
subsections.explanation: Adds extra information. Synonym: "in addition to."

subsections.title: BESIDES (preposition) - Meaning 2: except for
examples: Besides the weather, did you have a good time?
I'm available every day next week besides Monday.

subsections.title: BESIDES (preposition) - Meaning 3: besides + gerund (-ing)
examples: You can defend yourself besides kicking and punching.
Besides walking my dog, I don't get much exercise.
subsections.explanation: Same meaning as "apart from" / "in addition to," but with actions.

subsections.title: BESIDES (adverb) - Meaning: adding a reason / extra point
examples: I don't want to paint our bedroom gray. Besides, we're moving soon.
Don't worry about the gift. Besides, she won't remember who gave what.
subsections.explanation: Adds an extra reason. Similar to "moreover," but more natural in conversation.

subsections.title: BESIDES (adverb) - End position (less common)
examples: The gym offers classes, trainers, and much more besides.
We'll go hiking, roast marshmallows, and a lot more besides.
subsections.explanation: Used in fixed phrases meaning "plus more."

subsections.title: Using the wrong word changes meaning completely
structure: besides = except for / in addition to
examples: Leave all the bags besides the red one. → Leave all except the red one.
Leave all the bags beside the red one. → Put them next to the red one.
subsections.explanation: Because "beside" and "besides" sound similar, using the wrong one changes the meaning completely.
